title: 108_hr90
content: The Act may be cited as the "Good Medicine Cultural Competence Act of 2003". The Congress finds disparities in health care for racial and ethnic minorities, including higher mortality rates and serious disparities in health access outcomes. African-American children have higher rates of asthma and mortality compared to white children. African Americans face disparities in health outcomes, with higher rates of asthma, cancer mortality, advanced breast cancer diagnoses, diabetes death rates, heart disease mortality, and AIDS cases compared to whites and Latinos. The annual AIDS case rate is 4 times higher for Latinos than for whites. Infant mortality rates are twice as high among African-American infants as whites. Studies show that even well-meaning physicians demonstrate unconscious negative racial attitudes. The Cultural Competence Commission is established by this Act to address disparities in healthcare, including higher AIDS rates among Latinos and infant mortality rates among African-Americans. The Commission's duties include promoting cultural competence in healthcare. The Commission will conduct a study and submit a report on establishing standards in cultural competence education for medical professionals, mandating training requirements for high-quality patient care, collaborating with healthcare organizations to update clinical guidelines for patients of color, and engaging diverse organizations for leadership. The national consortium for African-American children prioritizes cultural competence training in school-based health settings, collaborates with diverse organizations to address the needs of vulnerable populations, and works with geriatric experts to improve access to culturally competent care for seniors in long-term care facilities. Increasing outcomes-based research to assess improvements in health care outcomes for minority patients through cultural competence education, broadening access to culturally competent health education, conducting a national policy forum to inform legislators about cultural competence programs, facilitating improvements in provider-patient interactions through cross-cultural education, health literacy training, and creating incentives for providers with expertise in cultural competence. Establishing a national cultural competence "think tank" with expert advisers in research, advocacy, education, public health policy, and human services. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 17 members appointed by various leaders and the President. Members serve for the life of the Commission and receive travel expenses but no pay. The Commission, consisting of 17 members, has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and obtain official data from government agencies to carry out its duties. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can use the United States mails like other government departments. The Commission, with 17 members, can conduct hearings, receive evidence, and obtain data from government agencies. Federal departments can detail personnel to assist the Commission, and the General Services Administrator can provide administrative support services. The Commission is required to submit a detailed report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations to Congress and the President within 4 years of the Act's enactment. It will terminate 180 days after submitting its final report.
